title: "Azar" blocky outdoor sign lettering
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/chopped_5030.jpg)

 [‹ (x) G-Star futuristic sans - custom drawn logo {Bert}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40518 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) "Squarell Technology" Brody-like condensed display sans - Badloc {Robert Farrelly} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.typophile.com/node/40489 "Go to next forum topic")
author: veniceissinking

comments.content: The Z appears to be an N turned on its side.
Ditto on the ’N’. That’s actually a very lovely set of letters. I don’t think there’s a font equal.
yeah. it definitely is. the place is pretty ghetto. i know i’m not giving you many letters to work with...but any ideas?

Again, it’s probably not a font. The [low waisted](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/tags/lowwaistedletters/) ’R’ is unique. You can get close with [Gotham](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.typophile.com/wiki/Gotham), [Klavika](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/process/klavika_bold_ot/?sample_text=ANAR&sample_size=74&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1) or [Proxima Nova](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/mark_simonson/proxima_nova_bold_ot/?sample_text=ANAR&sample_size=96&acs_ss=-1&acs_p=1&acs_pt=24&acs=1).
thanks. yeah the ’R’ is the most interesting thing to me - besides the ’N’ of course.

You might dig [Neutraface](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.houseind.com/index.php?page=showfont&id=18&subpage=viewfonts) and [Relay](http://web.archive.org/web/20080123174300/http:/www.fontshop.com/fonts/singles/font_bureau/relay_wide_black/) as well.

Ha! Love that N/Z. Hideous in a very folk artish way! The typeface, though, seems quite nice. Very Neturafacesque.

I wonder if the building originally housed a company called ANAR, who went bankrupt, and the new tenant figured they’d save a few bucks and just based their name of the existing signage. ;o)

(In fact, I know I’ve seen examples like that...companies moving in to existing building and basing their new name on part of the old signage...that’d make for a good blog.)
